posts.name: Ayush Sagar
posts.cooked: We’re using the NavX gyro for our swerve drive and I was confused whether to use getAngle or getYaw and which would be better. On the docs it says their both the same but I don’t get the point.
getAngle is a method implemented by WPILib’s Gyro interface–the NavX AHRS class has to implement it in order to be compatible with the Gyro interface.

What I understood from the javadocs:

getAngle() is accumulated forever, while getYaw() wraps to ±180

getAngle() is affected by setAngleAdjustment(), and getYaw() isn’t

Both methods are affected by zeroYaw().

https://www.kauailabs.com/public_files/navx-mxp/apidocs/java/com/kauailabs/navx/frc/AHRS.html

posts.name: Ayush Sagar
posts.cooked:
Right, another thing what do you mean by accumulated forever? And which would better to use for SwerveDriveKinematics and SwerveDriveOdometry because we are thinking of using getYaw() but everybody else uses getAngle().

Thanks for answering I’m new to FRC robotics code
basically if you spin around in circles getAngle() will just keep getting larger and larger and larger but getyaw90 will go to -180 after its gone past 180 and vise versa

Axion48:

which would better to use for SwerveDriveKinematics and SwerveDriveOdometry

I don’t see why it would matter for field-relative driving, because whether or not the angle accumulates, it still means the same position in reality. Angle 2 and angle 362 are the same thing.

An angle between 180 and -180 would probably be more convenient if you command the robot to get to a specific angle, because then you could tell the PID controller that 180 and -180 are the same thing (enableContinousInput()) and it would never have to go more than half a rotation at a time.
From what I remember, the odometry will normalize the angle anyway, so it shouldn’t matter.
Oh cool. So yeah, @Axion48 It doesn’t matter which one you use.
